what: How to know if my data has a frameshift?
text: couple ways know data contains frameshift. 1. MIRA output reference variants table MIRA output, frameshifts represented “~” character. can specifically filter instances “~” searching final column. , searched “NA” protein column “~” AA Variants column see 4 samples run frameshift NA amino acid position 44.   2. Nextclade output loaded NA samples Nextclade, sequences frameshift flagged output. Nextclade shows 4 NA samples (called aa, bb, hh, mm): Go https://clades.nextstrain.org/ Make sure select H3N2 NA pathogen   select input N2 sequences, results show orange “F” th QC column, 1 Gaps column, big red bar gene section far right, frameshift  3. Fixing frameshift JalView Select download button top right corner Nextclade’s output, choose nextclade.aligned.fasta  Open downloaded .fasta scroll position frameshift (hover Gaps Nextclade, tells us samples, gap nucleotide position 140)  Since downloaded aligned .fasta, see “-” character position 140 JalView. Notice Cs ? homopolymer:  TIP: JalView nucleotide size small difficult read? Click Format –> Font –> Size make bigger Next, need “fill” gap longer frameshift. since missing data, say certain C . just know nucleotide. Therefore, fill gap N character. Select gap clicking “-”, see red box around . Right click choose Selection, Edit, Edit Sequence  text box appear. Replace “-” uppercase “N” click OK successfully filled frameshift gap! Replace original sequences MIRA multifasta! First, open original .fasta Jalview select frameshift samples, type delete key keyboard. , can copy paste “fixed” sequence nextclade.aligned.fasta JalView window MIRA multifasta Jalview window save.
